Description: Hollow cast copper alloy furniture leg fragment: in the form of a lion's paw. The paw is surmounted by a rosette in high relief flanked by two volutes. There is a large area of woven textile imprint on one side.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Meroë (historic - Nubia), Royal City, site 299
Curator's comments: Similar bronze furniture feet are now in the Israel Museum, all from thrones of the type depicted on the Persepolis reliefs. Furniture of this type has also been found in Egypt and excavation archive shows that this piece was found with other elements belonging to a piece of furniture.
Bibliographic references: Curtis & Tallis 2005 / Forgotten Empire: The world of Ancient Persia (cat. 94, p. 102)
Tadmor 1974 / Fragments of an Achaemenid Throne from Samaria (pl. 6A-C)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2006 7 Mar-11 Jun, Barcelona, Fundacion La Caixa, 'L'imperi Oblidat' 2005-2006 Sept-Jan, London, BM, 'Forgotten Empire' 1995-2005 17 Nov- BM, G52/IRAN/8, from official opening 1994 16 Jun-23 Dec, BM, G49/IRAN/8/10 1975-ca 1990 Jul-, BM, Iranian Room [IR] case ?, no. 13 Persian Room, wall-case [WC] 15, top shelf
Acquisition name: Bequeathed by: Sir Robert Ludwig Mond (1939)
